ol.li: Understand the relationship between the determinant of a matrix and the volume of a parallelepiped.
Learn to use determinants to compute volumes of parallelograms and triangles.
Learn to use determinants to compute the volume of some curvy shapes like ellipses.
Pictures: parallelepiped, the image of a curvy shape under a linear transformation.

introduction.p: In this section we give a geometric interpretation of determinants, in terms of volumes. This will shed light on the reason behind three of the four defining properties of the determinant. It is also a crucial ingredient in the change-of-variables formula in multivariable calculus.

subsection.title: Parallelograms and Paralellepipeds
subsection.p: The determinant computes the volume of the following kind of geometric object.

statement.p:
The paralellepiped determined by n vectors v_1, v_2,\ldots,v_n in \R^n is the subset
P = \bigl\{a_1x_1 + a_2x_2 + \cdots + a_nx_n \bigm| 0 \leq a_1,a_2,\ldots,a_n\leq 1\bigr\}.

subsection.p: In other words, a parallelepiped is the set of all linear combinations of n vectors with coefficients in [0,1]. We can draw parallelepipeds using the parallelogram law for vector addition.

specialcase.title: The unit cube
Parallelograms

note.p: The parallelepiped defined by v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_n has zero volume if and only if the matrix with rows v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_n has zero determinant.

subsection.title: Determinants and Volumes
subsection.p: The key observation above is only the beginning of the story: the volume of a parallelepiped is always a determinant.

statement.p:
Let v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_n be vectors in \R^n, let P be the parallelepiped determined by these vectors, and let A be the matrix with rows v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_n. Then the absolute value of the determinant of A is the volume of P:
|\det(A)| = \vol(P).
\vol(P)Volume of a region

proof.p:
Since the four defining properties characterize the determinant, they also characterize the absolute value of the determinant. Explicitly, |\det| is a function on square matrices which satisfies these properties:
Doing a row replacement on A does not change |\det(A)|.
Scaling a row of A by a scalar c multiplies |\det(A)| by |c|.
Swapping two rows of a matrix does not change |\det(A)|.
The determinant of the identity matrix I_n is equal to 1.
The absolute value of the determinant is the only such function: indeed, by this , if you do some number of row operations on A to obtain a matrix B in row echelon form, then
|\det(A)| = \left|\frac{\text{(product of the diagonal entries of $B$)}} {\text{(product of scaling factors used)}}\right|.

subsection.p: Since \det(A) = \det(A^T) by the transpose property, the absolute value of \det(A) is also equal to the volume of the paralellepiped determined by the columns of A as well.

subsection.p: You might be wondering: if the absolute value of the determinant is a volume, what is the geometric meaning of the determinant without the absolute value? The next remark explains that we can think of the determinant as a signed volume. If you have taken an integral calculus course, you probably computed negative areas under curves; the idea here is similar.

remark.title: Signed volumes
remark.p: The on determinants and volumes tells us that the absolute value of the determinant is the volume of a paralellepiped. This raises the question of whether the sign of the determinant has any geometric meaning.

A 1\times 1 matrix A is just a number \mat a. In this case, the parallelepiped P determined by its one row is just the interval [0,a] if a \geq 0, and it is [a,0] if a\lt0. In this case, the sign of the determinant determines whether the interval is to the left or the right of the origin.
In higher dimensions, the notion of signed volume is still important, but it is usually defined in terms of the sign of a determinant.

subsection.title: Volumes of Regions

bluebox.p: If A is an n\times n matrix with corresponding matrix transformation T\colon\R^n\to\R^n, and if C is the unit cube in \R^n, then the volume of T(C) is |\det(A)|.

subsection.p: T(S)The image of a region under a transformation The notation T(S) means the image of the region S under the transformation T. In set builder notation, this is the subset T(S) = \bigl\{T(x)\mid x \text{ in } S\bigr\}.
In fact, T scales the volume of any region in \R^n by the same factor, even for curvy regions.

statement.p:
Let A be an n\times n matrix, and let T\colon\R^n\to\R^n be the associated matrix transformation T(x)=Ax. If S is any region in \R^n, then
\vol(T(S))=|\det(A)|\cdot\vol(S).

proof.p: By the first defining property, the image of a translate of \epsilon C is a translate of \epsilon P: T(x + \epsilon C) = T(x) + \epsilon T(C) = T(x) + \epsilon P. Since a translation does not change volumes, this proves that T scales the volume of a translate of \epsilon C by |\det(A)|.

solution.p: The area of the unit circle is \pi, so the area of S is \pi/2. The transformation T scales areas by a factor of |\det(A)| = |1 - 4| = 3, so \vol(T(S)) = 3\vol(S) = \frac{3\pi}2.

statement.p: Find the area of the interior E of the ellipse defined by the equation \left(\frac{2x-y}{2}\right)^2 + \left(\frac{y+3x}{3}\right)^2 = 1.

remark.title: Multiplicativity of |\det|\,
remark.p:
The above also gives a geometric reason for multiplicativity of the (absolute value of the) determinant. Indeed, let A and B be n\times n matrices, and let T,U\colon\R^n\to\R^n be the corresponding matrix transformations. If C is the unit cube, then
\begin{split} \vol\bigl(T\circ U(C)\bigr) = \vol\bigl(T(U(C))\bigr) \amp= |\det(A)|\vol(U(C)) \\ \amp= |\det(A)|\cdot|\det(B)|\vol(C) \\ \amp= |\det(A)|\cdot|\det(B)|. \end{split}
On the other hand, the matrix for the composition T\circ U is the product AB, so
\vol\bigl(T\circ U(C)\bigr) = |\det(AB)|\vol(C) = |\det(AB)|.
Thus |\det(AB)| = |\det(A)|\cdot|\det(B)|.
